title: Accumulation with water flowing in and out

content.question: At time t = 0 minutes, a tank contains 48 gallons of water. For 0 ≤ t ≤ 4 minutes, water flows into the tank at a rate of <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>E</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>t</mi><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mfrac> <mi>π</mi> <mn>4</mn> </mfrac> <mi>t</mi></mrow> <mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaWGfbWaaeWaa8aabaWdbiaadshaaiaawIcacaGLPaaacqGH9aqp caaIXaGaaGOmaiaadshaciGGZbGaaiyAaiaac6gadaqadaWdaeaape WaaSaaa8aabaWdbiabec8aWbWdaeaapeGaaGinaaaacaWG0baacaGL OaGaayzkaaaaaa@4539@ </annotation> </semantics> </math> gallons per minute, and water leaks out of the tank at a rate of <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>L</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac> <mrow> <mn>6</mn><msup> <mi>t</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaWGmbWaaeWaa8aabaWdbiaadshaaiaawIcacaGLPaaacqGH9aqp daWcaaWdaeaapeGaaGOnaiaadshapaWaaWbaaSqabeaapeGaaGOmaa aaaOWdaeaapeGaamiDaiabgUcaRiaaikdaaaaaaa@403E@ </annotation> </semantics> </math> gallons per minute. How many gallons of water are in the tank at time t = 4 minutes?

topic.text: 8.3: Using Accumulation Functions and Definite Integrals in Applied Contexts
